content.title: Above-Knee Amputation (AKA): Transfemoral Amputation
content.statement: Above-Knee Amputation (AKA): Transfemoral Amputation is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Pad that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Above-Knee Amputation (AKA): Transfemoral Amputation helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Above-Knee Amputation (AKA): Transfemoral Amputation include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Above-Knee Amputation (AKA): Transfemoral Amputation.

absolute: Failed BKA with inadequate residual limb
relative: Non-ambulatory patient with limited rehabilitation potential
Poor BKA healing prediction with limited life expectancy
Potential for BKA - should be attempted first
Young ambulatory patient (try BKA even with marginal perfusion)

standard.principle: Balance healing potential with prosthetic function

considerations.long_stump: Better prosthetic control, improved sitting balance
considerations.short_stump: Acceptable if needed for healing, prosthetic still possible
considerations.very_short: May be preferable to hip disarticulation

incision.pattern: Fish-mouth (equal anterior/posterior flaps) or medial-lateral bias
incision.length: One-half thigh circumference anteriorly and posteriorly

muscle_management.adductors: Critical for hip stability, anchor to lateral femur
muscle_management.quadriceps: Stabilize to prevent hip flexion contracture

bone_transection.level: Junction of middle and distal thirds of femur

closure.tension: Close without tension to prevent dehiscence

immediate: Hip extension positioning to prevent contracture

rehabilitation.prosthetic_candidacy: Assess motivation, cognition, upper body strength

vs_bka.energy: AKA requires 40-60% more energy for walking

definition.@value: Major limb amputation through the femur above the knee joint, with high healing rates but significantly reduced prosthetic rehabilitation potential.

presentation: Gangrene extending above ankle with poor BKA perfusion
Non-ambulatory patient with extensive limb necrosis

learning_objectives: Identify appropriate candidates for above-knee amputation
Describe the surgical technique including myodesis
Compare AKA and BKA outcomes for functional rehabilitation
Explain the energy expenditure differences between AKA and BKA
clinical_pearls: Try BKA first - only 30-50% of AKA patients achieve prosthetic ambulation
AKA energy expenditure is 60-100% above baseline for walking
Myodesis is critical - secure adductors to prevent hip instability
AKA heals better than BKA (95% vs 85%) but function is far worse
Prevent hip flexion contracture with proper positioning
